Award.AwardTitle: Forward Meson Production and Spin Asymmetries at RHIC
Award.AbstractNarration:
Proton high energy structure and the high energy proton-proton interaction depend on the spin and angular momentum of the underlying quarks and gluons. Unique tools are available at the Brookhaven Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC), which make it possible to study the role of the spin of the proton constituents in polarized proton collisions. RHIC is the first high energy polarized proton collider, where experimentalists can prepare the spin orientation of high energy protons before they collide. These polarized proton collisions are studied in the STAR detector with center of mass energies up to 500 GeV. When relativistic protons collide, they produce high energy fragments including neutral pions, etas and jets of particles. It is in the very forward region where particle production is most sensitive to the orientation of the proton spin. This research involves measurement of forward fragments in relativistic proton-proton collisions. In particular, transverse spin dependence is studied using a lead-glass calorimeter called the FMS, which is located in the forward region of the STAR detector. The goal is to characterize the dependence of this production on event kinematics. We test QCD related predictions of how the spin of the proton correlates with the spin of quarks and how this can modify the observable cross sections. This grant supports the collection of new RHIC FMS data and the analysis of that data. The objective is better understanding of the most basic questions about the nature of the proton.


The proton is understood to consist of quarks and gluons bound together by the strong force. This project investigates the role quark spin plays in the structure of the proton. This investigation involves the construction and ongoing operation of the FMS calorimeter in the STAR detector at Brookhaven National Lab. The FMS apparatus is available to all the other collaborators in STAR. The over 500 STAR collaborators work on a diverse range of physics topics, many of which are enhanced by the presence of the FMS. This research involves participation of undergraduate students who assist in fabrication of electronics and in analysis of data from the experiment. It involves graduate students, both those supported by this grant and others who use our apparatus. We also introduce interested middle school or high school students to our work and involve them where possible.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF grant supported Penn State participation in the STAR experiment at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) located at Brookhaven National Lab. RHIC can collide many combinations of relativistic protons and heavy nuclei. For proton beams, the colliding protons can be spin polarized along the longitudinal axis (the proton motion direction) or along a perpendicular transverse axis. The proton spin is related to the spin of the bound quarks and gluons that make up the proton and also related to the quark and gluon orbital angular momentum.  In high energy collisions, the pion particles produced in the very forward direction with transverse momentum larger than a few GeV/c are expected to come from fragmented jets of particles that are fragments of a single energetic quark in the incident proton.  These are the quarks with spins most highly correlated with the proton spin. Penn State has been a leader in fabrication and operation of the FMS forward calorimeter in STAR. It is with the FMS that fragments of these highest energy quarks in the proton can be observed. We have also been a leader in the analysis of these FMS data.

The transverse single spin asymmetry AN is defined as the ratio of the difference to the sum of cross sections for positive and negative proton spin alignments relative to a transverse axis.  One key point is that in an analysis of the collision process in Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) for transverse polarized protons, the spin asymmetry AN does not come about from the hard collision between a pair of colliding quarks. It comes about because of the interactions of the quark in the polarized proton as the quark passes through the rest of the proton, before or after the hard quark collision with a quark or gluon in the other beam. The current state of perturbative QCD theory is evolving now to explain these initial or final state interactions of the scattered quark. These AN asymmetry measurements that we have made provide new insights as to how these new theoretical approaches should evolve. These data provide guidance in the ongoing development of QCD, the theory of the nuclear force.

In the end, these measurements contribute essential new puzzle pieces toward a more complete picture of the proton as a composite object. 

Two important observations that we have made when measuring the forward neutral pion production asymmetry AN are demonstrated in the figures provided, measured in the RHIC run 12 (2012) and run 15 (2015). They demonstrate surprising results. From run 12, the asymmetry AN   is largest for events that appear the least jet-like with neutral pions observed in isolation. From Run 15, AN  is seen to be very similar when colliding polarized protons with a protons or a gold nuclear beam.  Finally, we also observe that the plot of the asymmetry vs. transverse momentum of the observed neutral pion does not seem to fall off at larger transverse momentum as basic arguments would suggest it should.

We have provided considerable opportunities for Penn State undergraduate to make very significant contributions to preparations and fabrication for the FMS detector. We believe that these truly substantive contributions by our undergraduate students to an important and successful detector at the currently operating US collider facility is a uniquely valuable educational experience.
